IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText:
MSP Unmarked vehicle O-12 is equipped with a mobile recording device. The accident and arrest were recorded. 

Defendant: Nicholas Wayne Osborne 
Date of Arrest: February 13, 2023
Times of Arrest: 1540 Hours 
DUI #: 23-008

CERTIFICATES AND TRAINING
* Trained in administering standardized field sobriety tests through the Maryland State Police and National Highway Traffic Safety Administration
* Trained and certified to operate Radar and Lidar through the Maryland State Police
* Trained in A.R.I.D.E. (Advanced Roadside Impaired Driving Enforcement)

VEHICLE IN MOTION (PHASE 1)

    On Monday, February 13, 2023 at approximately 1520 hours, I was on routine patrol in unmarked Maryland State Police cruiser O-12 on S/B Raven Rock Road (Rt. 491) heading towards Rt. 64. I had just passed Ritchie Rd. I was operating my in-car Golden Eagle radar unit (SERIAL #. While traveling S/B on Raven Rock Rd, I was monitoring the flow of traffic. During that time I observed a gray Chevrolet Traverse approaching my location at what appeared to be traveling at a very high rate of speed. Using the front antenna of the Golden Eagle radar unit, I activated the units front antenna and obtained a speed reading of 89 mph in a posted 55 mph zone. At the time the speed reading was recorded by the radar unit, the Chevrolet Traverse was the only vehicle traveling N/B. As the vehicle came closer I pulled my vehicle to the right shoulder of the roadway and activated my emergency equipment (lights only). I then observe the vehicle pass me from my position on the shoulder and observed the driver as a white male.  After the suspect vehicle passed, I had to wait for another vehicle to pass me which was coming from the rear. Once the other vehicle passed me, I made a U-turn and began to catch up with the Chevy Traverse. At that time, I was unable to see the Traverse as it had traveled around a bend in the roadway. As I was passing Ritchie Rd, I observed the Traverse had crashed into an embankment off the left shoulder of Ritchie Road. I pulled behind the vehicle and observed a male outside the vehicle rummaging around in the front passenger floorboard area of the vehicle. The male standing at the passenger door was the same male that was driving the vehicle as it passed me. The Maryland Registration was 8FD7926, I observed all the airbags deployed in the vehicle and heavy front-end damage. I did not observe any other passengers in the vehicle or leaving the scene. 

PERSONAL CONTACT (PHASE 2) 

    I made contact with the driver and asked him what happened. He advised he made an accidental turn, he also advised he did not need EMS. I identified the driver by his Maryland driver's license as Osborne, Nicholas Wayne (DOB 3/29/1990) of Cascade, MD. Osborne was listed as the second registered owner of the vehicle. While speaking to Osborne I observed extremely slurred speech, and I also observed that Osborne's eyes were glassy and bloodshot. I could not smell any alcohol at the time, but I was able to determine Osborne was on either CDS or impaired by some other substance. Osborne had a hard time being able to stand without swaying. He kept repeating himself asking if I was going to help him. I explained to Osborne that I was going to help him, but we had to make sure he did not need any medical treatment. I requested EMS to the scene to evaluate his medical condition and confirm he did not have any internal injury from the collision. EMS arrived at the scene and evaluated Osborne for any injuries. 

    Due to my observations, I asked Osborne to perform SFST. Osborne advised he did not want to perform any SFST tests. I explained to Osborne the reasons why I felt he was impaired, and again he advised he would not perform any of the SFST tests.

    After giving Osborne several minutes to elect to perform the SFST test, I arrested Osborne for DUI. While handcuffing Osborne he was swaying and had trouble standing. M/Tpr. Kocevar walked Osborne to my patrol vehicle and placed him in the front passenger seat. Once he was in the seat and contained in my patrol vehicle, I detected an extremely strong odor of an alcoholic beverage coming from his person and breath. At that time, I confirmed the impairment was alcohol-related. 

ARREST

Based on the following, I had reason to believe Osborne was operating a motor vehicle under the influence of alcohol:

* Osborne was traveling 89 mph in a posted 55 mph zone and failed to slow down when he observed my emergency equipment
* Osborne admitted he was in a collision on Ritchie Rd. 
* Slow and sluggish movements.
* Slurred speech and constantly repeated himself. 
* Bloodshot, glassy eyes. 
* Strong odor of an alcoholic beverage emitting from Osborne's breath.
* My training, knowledge, and experience of 17 years of being a Trooper with the Maryland State Police. 

    I arrested Osborne for driving under the influence at approximately 1540 hours. Osborne read the DR-15, Advice of Rights in my patrol vehicle at 1604 hours. 

    Osborne REFUSED to take the breath test. I then transported Osborne to his residence which was approximately 5 miles away. Osborne was released to his wife, La Toya Danielle Osborne. When La Toya first observed Osborne she advised "he is drunk, there is no question it is alcohol". Osborne was unable to stand on the front lawn without moving and falling over.  

CASE CLOSED BY ARREST

    All events occurred in Washington County, Maryland
